metadata.case_name: Gurbux Rai Harbux Rai v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: Gurbux Rai Harbux Rai (assessee) is a registered firm carrying on business in piece goods and commission agents, with head office at Kanpur and branch at Farrukhabad.
During chargeable accounting periods July 4, 1943 to June 21, 1944 and June 22, 1944 to July 10, 1945, partners were Gurbux Rai and Harbux Rai, each representing his joint family, with equal shares.

Assessee informed Tax Officer of partition in Gurbux Rai's joint family and reconstitution of partnership from July 4, 1943: Kanpur firm with two original partners equally; Farrukhabad with Harbux Rai (8 annas), Chameli Devi (4 annas), Gopaldas (4 annas).

For Income-tax assessment year 1944-45 (relevant to account year ending June 21, 1944), ITO rejected partition claim as afterthought to avoid tax, assessed entire income (Kanpur and Farrukhabad) as assessee's.
Excess Profits Tax Officer assessed entire income of both businesses in hands of assessee firm, consequential on income-tax assessment.

Assessee appealed ITO's income-tax order to Appellate Assistant Commissioner (AAC), who on October 10, 1947 held partial partition of Gurbux Rai's movable property near Asadh Samvat 2000, Farrukhabad conducted by separate firm (Harbux Rai, Chameli Devi, Gopaldas); ITO modified income-tax assessments for 1944-45 and 1945-46.

Excess Profits Tax Officer served notice dated February 3/6, 1951 under s.10A, calling to show cause why adjustments for avoidance of excess profits tax; on February 21, 1951 passed order under s.15 modifying original EPT assessments, including Farrukhabad income in assessee's total.
Assessee appealed EPT orders to AAC (dismissed), then Tribunal (confirmed).
Tribunal referred two questions to Allahabad High Court under s.21 EPT Act r/w s.66(1) IT Act 1922.
Allahabad High Court answered both questions in negative: no definite information under s.15; no competence for s.10A without valid s.15 proceeding (judgment dated May 22, 1964 in ITR No.189/1953).
Supreme Court appeals preferred against High Court order.
Parallel proceedings in Civil Appeals Nos.741-743/1966 (decided Aug 2, 1968) and ITR No.118/1962 (Jul 31, 1969): High Court held s.10A applicable to avoid tax via partial partition, final.
SC directed Tribunal for supplementary statement on whether s.10A proceedings in course of s.15 (order Jan 21, 1971).
Supplementary statement: Notices under s.15 issued first on Feb 3, 1951, then s.10A same day; s.15 proceedings pending when s.10A action taken; assessee present, denied prior s.10A notice.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts and circumstances there was any definite information within the meaning of s.15 EPT Act by virtue of which EPT Officer was competent to reopen excess profits tax assessments?
Whether in the circumstances, EPT Officer was competent to apply provisions of s.10A and make necessary adjustments in pursuance thereto in the revised assessment under s.15?

petitioner_arguments.text: EPT Officer had no definite information under s.15; all materials already before him at original assessment, no new information; change of opinion not sufficient.
EPT Officer not competent to pass order under s.10A merely to make adjustment in revised assessment under s.15; s.10A only in pending valid assessment proceeding.
No objection taken that s.15 notice issued before s.10A, but notices same date; no escapement examined by AAC in IT proceedings.

respondent_arguments.text: Definite information from AAC order dated Oct 10, 1947 holding partial partition; enabled discovery of escaped assessment.
s.15 proceedings initiated first (notice Feb 3, 1951), pending when s.10A applied; s.10A power exercisable in course of original or reassessment.
Main purpose of partial partition was avoidance of excess profits tax liability.

court_reasoning.text: s.10A not independent proceeding; power to adjust liability exercisable in course of original assessment or reassessment under s.15; requires pending s.15 proceeding.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court right that s.10A only in pending valid EPT proceeding.

court_reasoning.text: Supplementary statement confirms s.15 notices issued first on Feb 3, 1951, then s.10A same day; s.15 proceedings pending when s.10A started; not hypertechnicality.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Proceedings under s.15 commenced before s.10A action.

court_reasoning.text: AAC order Oct 10, 1947 on partial partition is definite information for s.15; not mere change of opinion, from superior authority; EPT Officer competent to examine avoidance under s.10A post s.15 initiation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Information from AAC decision enables jurisdiction under s.15, analogous to IT Act s.34(1)(b).

holdings.text: There was definite information under s.15 from AAC order, making reopening competent.
EPT Officer competent to apply s.10A in course of pending s.15 reassessment proceedings.

precedents_cited.case_name: R.B. Bansilal Abirchand Firm v. Commissioner of Income Tax, M.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: ITO jurisdiction under s.34(1)(b) IT Act on info from superior authorities/court, in pari materia with s.15 EPT Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Assistant Controller of Estate Duty, Hyderabad v. Nawab Sir Osman Ali Khan Bahadur, H.E.H. The Nizam of Hyderabad & Others
precedents_cited.relevance: Similar to above on jurisdiction from superior authority decisions.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gurbux Rai Harbux Rai v. Commissioner of Income-tax, U.P. (Civil Appeals Nos.741-743/1966)

statutes_cited.name: Excess Profits Tax Act, 1940
statutes_cited.relevance: s.10A for adjustments against tax avoidance transactions; s.15 for reopening on definite information of escaped assessment; s.10A exercisable in pending s.15 proceedings.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference to High Court; analogy for definite information.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeals with costs, answering both referred questions in favour of Revenue: EPT Officer had definite information under s.15 and was competent to apply s.10A in pending s.15 proceedings.
outcome.relief_granted: Appeals allowed; High Court answers reversed.

key_quotes.text: "S. 10-A does not contemplate an independent proceeding. Section 10-A merely confers power upon the Excess Profits Tax Officer to make adjustments with respect to liability to excess profits tax."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "It is abundantly clear... that notice under s.15 was issued first and the notice under s.10A was issued thereafter."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Confirms sequence from supplementary statement, upholding jurisdiction.

key_quotes.text: "The Appellate Assistant Commissioner had made an order on October 10, 1947... That was certainly an information which came into the possession of the Excess Profits Tax Officer."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Identifies source of definite information for s.15.
